description: try this creamy, sweet potato casserole inspired by Ruth's Chris, ready in just 45 minutes! Made with rich sweet potatoes and topped with a crunchy pecan crust, it's great for holiday gatherings or family dinners. Save this crowd-pleaser for your next occasion! üç†
ingredients: 4 medium sweet potatoes, peeled and cubed
instructions: In a large pot, boil the sweet potatoes until tender, about 15 minutes. Drain and mash them in a large bowl.
Add brown sugar, milk, melted butter, vanilla extract, cinnamon, and nutmeg to the mashed sweet potatoes. Mix until smooth and well combined.
Transfer the sweet potato mixture to a greased baking dish and spread it evenly.
In a separate bowl, combine chopped pecans and mini marshmallows (if using). Sprinkle this mixture over the sweet potato layer.
Bake in the preheated oven for 25-30 minutes, or until the topping is golden brown and the casserole is heated through.
tips: Here's the thing: For the best results, choose sweet potatoes that are firm and free from blemishes. Boiling them until just tender ensures a creamy texture when mashed. Avoid over-mixing the sweet potato mixture to keep it fluffy. If you want to make this ahead, prepare the casserole up to the baking step and refrigerate it. Bake it fresh before serving for a warm, comforting dish. To reheat leftovers, cover with foil and warm in the oven at 350¬∞F (175¬∞C) for about 15-20 minutes.

structured_content.headline: What Goes In and What You Can Swap

structured_content.content: When making this casserole, the main ingredient is sweet potatoes. Look for firm, vibrant sweet potatoes without blemishes for the best flavor and texture. They should be rich in color, indicating ripeness. For the sweetener, brown sugar adds a deep, caramel-like flavor that enhances the sweetness of the potatoes. If you prefer a healthier option, consider using maple syrup instead. The pecans not only provide a crunchy topping but also add a nutty flavor that complements the dish beautifully. For those with dietary restrictions, you can substitute dairy milk with almond or oat milk for a dairy-free version. Essential tools include a large pot for boiling, a mixing bowl for combining ingredients, and a baking dish for cooking.

upload.context: Fresh sweet potatoes, brown sugar, pecans, and spices arranged on a kitchen counter, ready for casserole preparation.

structured_content.content: Before you start cooking, gather all your ingredients and tools. Begin by peeling and cubing the sweet potatoes, then set a large pot of water to boil. Once boiling, add the sweet potatoes and cook for about 15 minutes until they are tender. Drain the sweet potatoes and mash them in a large bowl. While mashing, incorporate the brown sugar, milk, melted butter, vanilla, and spices until smooth. Transfer the mixture to a greased baking dish, spreading it evenly. In a separate bowl, mix the pecans with marshmallows if desired, then sprinkle over the sweet potato layer. Bake in a preheated oven for 25-30 minutes until the topping is golden brown.

note.label: Don't Mess This Up
note.content:
• Temperature precision: Bake at 350¬∞F (175¬∞C) to achieve a perfectly cooked casserole without burning the topping.
  • Common mistake to avoid: Over-mashing the sweet potatoes can lead to a gummy texture; mash just until smooth.
  • Perfect doneness indicator: The casserole is ready when the topping is golden brown and the edges are bubbling.
  • Storage & reheating: Store leftovers in an airtight container in the fridge for up to 3 days. Reheat in the oven at 350¬∞F (175¬∞C) for best results.

note.label: Tricks I've Learned
note.content:
• Restaurant technique: Toasting the pecans before adding them to the casserole enhances their flavor and adds depth.
  • Ingredient prep secret: Bring sweet potatoes to room temperature before boiling for even cooking.
  • Timing strategy: Prepare the sweet potato mixture ahead of time and refrigerate; bake just before serving for a fresh, warm dish.
  • Presentation hack: Use a spatula to create decorative swirls in the sweet potato mixture before baking for a visually appealing presentation.
